description: from Latin conglobare, from com- (“together”) + globus (“ball”)

adjectives.description: conglobate (comparative more conglobate, superlative most conglobate)

entries.meaning: Shaped like or formed into a ball.

verbs.description: conglobate (third-person singular simple present conglobates, present participle conglobating, simple past and past participle conglobated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To form into a globe or ball.
examples: How rich a dower was yours!By how much toil of sinew and of mindCollected, conglobated, were Earth’s storesTreasured in Rome,—the Eternal!—throne assignedBy Nature and the Gods for sway of human kind!
